p: According to the literature, the essential oils isolated from A. alba and A. koreana seeds and cones showed a stronger antimicrobial activity against S. aureus, E. faecalis, and E. faecium (MIC: 10–23 μL/mL) [ 16] than those isolated from A. concolor seeds and cones (MIC: 26–30 μL/mL). It was probably caused by a higher concentration of oxygenated derivatives of terpenes in silver and Korean fir oils. Both seed and cone essential oils of white fir exhibited similar antibacterial properties against E. coli and K. pneumoniae as those of silver fir and Korean fir seed and cone oils (MIC: 25.5–34 μL/mL) described in the literature [ 16].
